reviews.review: [b][u]Killing Floor[/u][/b] may be an old game, but as the saying goes, it has [b]aged like fine wine[/b]! The sequel may be an improved version, but the original game still holds great nostalgia for me. More than a decade after its release, it can still proudly count itself among the best co-op games ever made, bringing extreme violence and gore together with immersive survival horror in a way that has continually inspired many games that came after it.

This is a pretty good old-school zombie shooter from 2009. I've played it every now and then, never becoming very good at it. It has a good pace, lots of maps, interesting classes and zed (monster) types.

Recently I rediscovered the game, have been watching video guides, looking up tips about classes/maps etc. Despite the game being 13 years old!
I've even managed to win a few games on the highest difficulty, meeting some cool people on the way. The community is not very large, but it is active. You can easily find games on all 5 difficulty levels. And if you can't, just start a game and someone is likely to join you.

My tips for new KF1 players - ask for advice, spectate games on higher difficulties, and look up guides/videos on the class you like.

Don't expect much from graphics, take the game for what it is and have fun!  :)
Game runs great on both PC and Mac.

coming from KF2 in 2022, KF1 is much more grounded in realism not like the game is entirely realistic, but just much grounded than kf2 , also much more unforgiving, you have to play smart and aslo work together, it's also way more horror like then kf2, i like it! just try and have a friend get it as well..  or go solo like me, both fun, overall great game, 8/10

If you're contemplating buying this game, just do it. This game is an entire childhood of fun with a ton of mods that make playing it with even just one other person a lot of fun.

It's a great game, but its gets boring quickly. It doesn't have the same fast-paced energy that Left 4 Dead 2 has. Instead you're just walking around shooting zombies over and over and over. Leveling up to 6 (the max) is a massive grind!

But it's still quite good. Basically the zombie mode of Call of Duty if it was its own game with a lot more thought and effort put into it. I can't bring myself to recommend the sequel though because of the micro-transactions.

Synopsis:
Who are you? One of many mercenaries located in the European continent dealing with the machinations of a madman hellbent on creating zombie clones. Why? Something about women rejecting him or something. Anyway, you need to blast away some zombies. Come and get em with lovely big guns.

Mechanics:
6 Perks for specific playstyles will help you for specific situations.
+Want to heal your team? Medic.
+Want to be aggressive and up close? Berserker.
+Want to clear a room while looking into the whites of Zed eyes? Support Specialist.
+Want snipe heads? Sharpshooter.
+Want to burn em all? Firebug.
+Want to tag various stragglers rifles blazing? Commando.

Big, Mean, and Scary?
+Who is that menacing chainsaw zombie? Skrake! Watch out. They will charge if hurt enough, so be ready to unload!
+Who is that daunting zombie covered in metal plates and glowing lights? Fleshpound! GTFO! Looks at you for too long; it charges. Hit it too fast; it charges.

Achievements?
It's the long haul. Expect to spend hundreds of hours completing these things. Expect to struggle with the highest difficulty whether going alone or with strangers.

Oh no! You can't get the "Not a Warhammer Achievement" in Killing Floor despite 100% Dwarfs?! the game? Guess what, the achievement is broken in both games. Sorry, but you'll need to follow the steps community made guides provide. There is no legitimate method to earning it, but after all the pain I endured playing two games to near completion, I feel that these fixes are justified. Good luck!
